文章內容:
“Humanity is altering earth’s life support system”. 

Take a look at this new data visualization to see the latest climate science from the IPCC in just 3 minutes and 336 words: http://bit.ly/18Sq3ii

Marking the 16 Days of Activism against Gender Violence, a new interactive tool from the World Health Organization (WHO) provides 16 ways to address violence against women in the context of the HIV epidemic – from working with men and boys to promoting effective laws and more. 

Take a look at: http://goo.gl/o8SHpS

The world must close a 70% gap between the food that a global population of 9.6 billion will need in 2050 and the food available today, according to a report released on Monday by the UN and partners. 

This must be done sustainably, in a way that creates opportunities for the rural poor, limits clearing of forests and reduces greenhouse gas emissions, say the report. 

Find out more at: http://j.mp/1eTLkta

With more than two thirds of young workers’ potential not fully utilized, decent jobs for youth should be at the top African development agenda, finds a new International Labour Organization (ILO) report. While African countries have experienced incredible growth over the last decade, the quantity and quality of jobs for youth remains a huge challenge.

Find out more at: http://bit.ly/1eRIDYV
留言: ["This is indeed a great initiative, engaging in a string of talks on how we can solve Afriica's youth unemplloyment. The topic is very important because if u cannot devise means to solve this problem , Africa will be faced with a an angry backlash from our young people"]

文章內容:
The General Conference of the United Nations Industrial Development Organization  (UNIDO) is taking place this week in Lima, Peru.  The Conference is an opportunity for countries to renew their commitment to inclusive and sustainable industrial development and to strengthen cooperation among regions. 

Find out more about UNIDO and get the conference agenda, details on side events and more at: http://j.mp/1gfGff5

There are currently more than a billion people with disabilities around the world –around 15% of the population of the planet – and too many of them of working age don’t have the opportunity to get a decent job. 

In his latest LinkedIn Influencer piece, “Disability is Not Inability”, Ban Ki-moon highlights “what many employers already know – that hiring persons with disabilities is not charity, just good sense”. 

Read his piece in full at: http://j.mp/18yrLr5
留言: ['that is verry great of UN sec..Ban ki-moon.']

文章內容:
Over 1 billion people, approx 15% of the world’s population, live with some form of disability. Tuesday is the International Day of Persons with Disabilities, with theme “Break Barriers, Open Doors”. 

Marking the Day, Ban Ki-moon said that we must remove all barriers that affect the inclusion and participation of persons with disabilities in society, including through changing attitudes that fuel stigma and institutionalize discrimination.

Find out more at: http://j.mp/1fZZJH6

Access to water and sanitation facilities is vital for healthy school environment.

Yet less than half of all schools in Afghanistan have basic water and sanitation facilities. Diarrhoeal diseases linked to poor hand-washing and hygiene practices and inadequate sanitation can result in death.

Watch how UNICEF is helping to address hygiene issues in Afghan schools: http://j.mp/I1o3cA
留言: ['Sanitation must become priority in donor school programs']

文章內容: What comes next in the process to craft a post-2015 sustainable development framework? Get updates and resources, and find out the key events to watch out for next year at: http://j.mp/1dyLMjb
留言: ['Awesome :)']

文章內容:
World AIDS Day is on Sunday. UNAIDS reports that the world is closing in on MDG 6: Globally the AIDS epidemic has been halted and reversed— and the race is on to reach universal access to HIV treatment. Find out more at: http://j.mp/1ccU3pG

Marking the Day, Ban Ki-moon says that he is more optimistic than ever. Read his full message at: http://j.mp/1caYaCQ

Female genital mutilation/cutting (FGM/C) is still prevalent in some countries.

In Guinea, some 96% of girls and women aged 15 to 49 years have undergone FGM/C. Read this story from UNICEF about 12-year-old Fatou, who had the courage to speak out about her experience: http://j.mp/1cOoMYt

News from International Labour Organization (ILO): Employment is crucial for successful HIV treatment. An ILO study released ahead of World AIDS Day finds that people living with HIV who are employed are almost 40% more likely to stick to HIV treatment than those without a job. 

Find out more at: http://bit.ly/1aXkyiC

HIV infections in children aged 0-14 have been reduced by more than half since 2001. For the first time in the history of the HIV epidemic, the global community has the knowledge, experience and tools to achieve an #AIDSfree generation. 

Find out more in a new report from UNICEF: http://uni.cf/AIDSfree13

Delivering food to people in need can be tricky. Sometimes World Food Programme drivers and mechanics have to think creatively when faced with roads that are too rocky, too muddy, or just plain impassable.

Read three short stories to see what WFP is doing to solve the problems on the road: http://bit.ly/HwatOC

文章內容:
Birth certificates are essential for children in C?te d’Ivoire to enroll in school and get an education. However, as many as three out of 10 births go unregistered there due to the conflicts and crises that have plagued the country.

See how the UN and partners are helping thousands of children get registered for a better future. http://ow.ly/qwD2L

Ahead of #WorldAIDSDay on 1 December, see the reduction of new HIV infections over time in this new UNAIDS infographic. 

New HIV infections among adults and children were estimated at 2.3 million in 2012, a 33% reduction since 2001. AIDS-related deaths have also dropped by 30% since the peak in 2005 as access to antiretroviral treatment expands.

Find out more at: http://j.mp/1iPbPSZ
留言: ['I think this is promising']

文章內容:
Measles is one of the leading illnesses of children under 5  in Nigeria, where a nationwide campaign is targeting almost 30 million children for vaccination. 

Watch how UNICEF is helping: http://uni.cf/17d4UQR

Citizen insecurity is a challenge that is thwarting the social and economic development in every country in Latin America, which remains the most unequal and insecure region of the world.

Find out more in a new report from United Nations Development Programme - UNDP: http://j.mp/19i5jff

Super Typhoon Haiyan has brought terrible destruction to the Philippines, killing thousands of people and leaving millions homeless. More than 13 million people have been affected by the Typhoon, including 230,000 pregnant and 156,000 lactating women who are in need.

Get more information and find out how you can help UNFPA meet the urgent needs of women and young people in disasters: http://bit.ly/GFc6oK

More than 2 million adolescents between the ages of 10 and 19 years are living with HIV, yet many do not receive the care and support that they need, according to the World Health Organization (WHO).

The failure to support effective  HIV services for adolescents has resulted in a 50% increase in reported AIDS-related deaths in this group, compared with the 30% decline seen in the general population from 2005 to 2012.

Find out more about WHO's new recommendations for adolescents: http://j.mp/1eu45mO

Marking the International Day to End Violence against Women on Monday, Ban Ki-moon says that violence against women and girls harms our common humanity and has joined people around the world in wearing orange to show his support for the cause. Watch his video message at http://j.mp/19WlBe9

Find out more at http://j.mp/1gbMDnt

Africa climate adaptation costs could soar to USD $350 billion annually by 2070 if warming hits 3.5-4°C, according to a new UNEP report.

"Missing the 2°C window  will not only cost governments billions of dollars but will risk the lives and livelihoods of hundreds of millions of people on the African continent and elsewhere," said UNEP Executive Director, Achim Steiner.  

Find outmore: http://j.mp/1dTRZ5m

25 November is the International Day to End Violence against Women and marks the beginning of the 16 Days of Activism against Gender Violence. From 25 November to 10 December, people around the world come together to SayNO - UNiTE to End Violence Against Women and girls. 

Check out stories, messages, facts & figures and more from UN Women and find out how you can take action! http://owl.li/qYy2K

文章內容:
This week the ITU and United Nations ESCAP  launched the first interactive information superhighway to help bridge the digital divide in the Asia-Pacific region. 

“What we call the ‘digital divide’ is in fact an income divide, a gender divide, an education divide and a knowledge divide,” said Noeleen Heyzer, ESCAP Executive Secretary. 

Get more details at: http://j.mp/19OQFwu

Each year, while countless species are driven closer to extinction, criminals generate billions of dollars from the sale of protected wildlife products.

Buying and selling protected wildlife is a crime. Don't be part of it!

Watch this new UNODC - United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime video with Chinese actress Li Bingbing to find out more: http://j.mp/171MW1A
留言: ['Barbarians! Lets campaign against this cruelty.']

文章內容:
Got six seconds? Check out this Vine showing what is needed to achieve A World At School. 

Find out more about efforts to achieve quality education for all from the UN Global Education First Initiative: http://j.mp/19qYGYd

The International Year of Family Farming kicks off on Friday. Small-scale farming is closely linked to global food security, boosts local economies and safeguards agro bio-diversity.The Year is an opportunity to highlight the challenges faced by family farmers and help find ways to support them. 

Learn more about why family farming is important from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO): http://j.mp/1e3J3ua

In a recent interview with The Guardian, Ban Ki-moon explains why partnerships are key to fulfilling the MDGs. “Technology has globalised communications. Now we must globalise compassion and citizenship”. 

Read more: http://j.mp/17IJ6gm

Ban Ki-moon rode a bamboo bike at the Warsaw Climate Change Conference this week! 

Ghana Bamboo Bikes are made by a youth-led, non-profit enterprise committed to the economic empowerment of youth by taking advantage of the abundant bamboo raw materials in Ghana to manufacture and assemble high-quality bamboo bikes that are affordable and suitable for the road conditions and terrain in Ghana.

Find out more: http://ghanabamboobikes.org/

Africa Industrialization Day on Wednesday focuses on the crucial role of job creation and entrepreneurship in eradicating poverty in the region. Find out more:  http://j.mp/1fSwKlN

Get regular African news and analysis from UN Africa Renewal.

ITU Telecom World  2013 is now taking place in Bangkok, Thailand, exploring the theme "Embracing change in a digital world.” Everyone can be part of the event through interactive panel debates, workshops and showfloor sessions. Find out how and access the live stream and daily highlights at: http://j.mp/Idh8ND

For updates follow @ITU #ITUWORLD and #ITUWORLDLIVE on Twitter and join the Telecom World G+ community at: http://ow.ly/qTJ00

The UN Climate Change Conference continues in Warsaw this week. Speaking there on Tuesday, Ban Ki-moon said that the world need look no further than the catastrophe in the Philippines to understand the dangerous consequences of climate change. He urged leaders to rise to the challenge of agreeing a climate deal by 2015. Read more: http://j.mp/1isgqdK

Take a look at “Notes from Warsaw” for regular conference updates:http://j.mp/17S3uvG

文章內容:
The world is facing a global sanitation crisis: 2.5 billion people do not have access to proper sanitation, such as a decent toilet or latrine. In his latest LinkedIn Influencer piece on World Toilet Day, Ban Ki-moon says better sanitation isn’t just life-saving, it’s an excellent economic investment. 

Read more at: http://j.mp/18kBChV

文章內容:
In Cambodia, women are embracing green growth by are taking up cookstove production, making hundreds of improved cookstoves every month, which reduces their wood consumption and increases their income. 

Get the full story on the United Nations Development Programme - UNDP-supported cookstove training project: http://j.mp/19QLY8m

Tuesday is the first-ever World Toilet Day. 2.6 billion people lack access to proper sanitation, such as a decent toilet or latrine. Yet improved sanitation is not only a human right but a great economic investment. 

Marking the Day, Ban Ki-moon said that by working together we can improve the health and well-being of one-third of the human family. 

Find out more at http://j.mp/18iD0Se
留言: ['we can end poverty together! Lets try']

文章內容:
Only 10 per cent of domestic workers worldwide are covered by the same laws and legislation as other workers. Many of them are also subject to deplorable working conditions, labour exploitation and human rights abuses. But the situation is changing.

Find out more from International Labour Organization (ILO): bit.ly/1eYZqct
留言: ['El Club UNESCO Cege@ de M?xico y la FLACACU, los invita a promover y colaborar con la iniciativa del Sr. Georges Christophides, Presidente de la WFUCA del Pasaporte para la ?tica Global.', 'LIFE GOES ON']

文章內容:
UNICEF is working with country governments, partners, professional associations and parent groups to spread awareness about prematurity.

They are together developing plans to include cost-effective strategies, such as antenatal corticosteroids and kangaroo care, to reduce pre-term deaths.

Read a story about how UNICEF is helping on this issue in East Asia and the Pacific: http://j.mp/1av3M9w

Safe, effective, affordable vaccines could play a critical role in defeating malaria causes an estimated 660,000 deaths each year from 219 million cases. 

The updated 2013 World Health Organization (WHO)  Malaria Vaccine Technology Roadmap recommends that the world should aim to have vaccines which reduce malaria cases by 75% licensed by 2030. 

Read more: http://j.mp/1dudzNE

Watch this video from Roll Back Malaria: http://j.mp/19nnSii

Saturday is International Day for Tolerance. A lack of tolerance can lead to discrimination and keep some kids out of school. Read more about education’s unique power to boost tolerance and reduce discrimination: http://j.mp/17YbtYb

Find out more about global efforts to put education first: http://j.mp/19qYGYd

16 November is World Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease Day.

Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) is an umbrella term used to describe chronic lung diseases that cause limitations in lung airflow.

The most common symptoms of COPD are breathlessness, excessive sputum production, and a chronic cough. COPD is a under-diagnosed, life threatening lung disease that may progressively lead to death.

Read more: http://j.mp/178zSHz

Thursday is World Diabetes Day, which this year is being marked with the theme “Protect Our Future”. 347 million people worldwide have diabetes and the disease is predicted to become the seventh leading cause of death in the world by 2030. More than 80% of people with diabetes live in low- and middle-income countries.

Find out more and get facts & figures from the World Health Organization (WHO): http://j.mp/1boXLca

Take al look at this video on Qatar's diabetes problem: http://j.mp/1bvnsLq

Sunday  is World Prematurity Day. Preterm birth is the world's largest killer of newborn babies, causing more than one million deaths each year, yet 75% could be saved with simple, cost-effective measures. 

Find out more at World Prematurity Day and visit http://j.mp/1id4TPj for more details.

The world will be short of 12.9 million health-care workers by 2035, finds a newly released World Health Organization (WHO) report. If not addressed now, the shortage will have serious implications for the health of billions of people across all regions of the world.

Some key causes for the shortage are an aging health workforce with staff retiring or leaving for better paid jobs without being replaced, while not enough young people are entering the profession. 

Find out more: http://goo.gl/XOx93J

2013 is currently on course to be among the top ten warmest years since modern records began in 1850, according to the latest climate status statement released by the World Meteorological Organization on Wednesday. The first nine months, January to September, tied with 2003 as the seventh warmest such period on record. 

Find out more at http://j.mp/171Z7LT

The UN Climate Change Conference is taking place this week at the National Stadium in Warsaw, Poland. At the meeting, leaders from around the world are working towards a new agreement to cut climate-altering greenhouse gas emissions, made all the more urgent by the devastation in Philippines from Typhoon Haiyan.

Check out “Notes from Warsaw” for regular conference updates: http://j.mp/17S3uvG

Get more information and the conference schedule at http://j.mp/17cSgfq

文章內容:
Check out the chalk art by United Nations International School(UNIS) Middle School students in support of the MDGs!

The students send encouragement to all individuals working with the UN through collages of their chalk art.

See more: http://j.mp/1cMIWXA

Tuesday is World Pneumonia Day. Pneumonia is the single largest cause of death in children under five -- last year alone, 1.1 million children under five died from pneumonia, the bulk of whom were less than 2 years old. The impact of pneumonia is worst among the poorest and most marginalized it can be prevented with simple interventions.

Find out more at http://j.mp/1bdkAml 

Photo: UNICEF

Typhoon Haiyan, known locally as Yolanda is said to be the strongest ever to have made landfall anywhere in the world and has left nearly half a million people in the Philippines homeless. 

The Government of the Philippines took preventative steps to save lives by moving people from coastal and low-lying areas known to be prone to flash flooding and landslides. Find out more about creating disaster-resilient societies at http://j.mp/wxOeVN

The UN is now working closely with the Government to reach those affected, as the number of reported casualties continues to rise. 

Get the latest update from World Food Programme on its emergency response and find out how you can help at http://goo.gl/ZEJx9U

Two-thirds of the earth's population are predicted to be living in cities by 2050. Read why sustainable cities are central to global development in this United Nations Development Programme - UNDP article: on.undp.org/qbQwX

Get facts and figures and find out more about sustainable cities at http://j.mp/1g7HzTu

Did you know that an estimated 2/3 of poor livestock keepers – around 400 million people – are women? Find out more from Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) about women’s role in agriculture and farming, and its impact on development at: http://bit.ly/16vkFwR

文章內容:
In this video, actress and UNICEF supporter Freida Pinto says it's time to fight for girls who aren't in school. Take a look: http://j.mp/1gNjlPO  

Find out more about progress towards ensuring access to education for all children: http://j.mp/g2fd09
A child in Africa dies from malaria every minute. Find out how you can help Nothing But Nets in the fight to end this preventable and treatable disease. Send a net and save a life: http://j.mp/I9PgHx

World Health Organization (WHO) and UNICEF announced that over 20 million children will be vaccinated in Syria and neighbouring countries against polio.

A week after the Middle East declared a polio emergency in the region, mass vaccination against polio and other vaccine-preventable diseases are under way.

See more at: http://goo.gl/ul8Gie

文章內容:
10 November marks the World Science Day for Peace and Development. The purpose of the Day is to renew the national, as well as the international commitment to science for peace and development and to stress the responsible use of science for the benefit of society.

The Day also aims at raising public awareness of the importance of science and to bridge the gap between science and societies.

Find out more: http://j.mp/tRzhYd

African countries recently agreed to curb illegal timber trade in the Congo Basin, which covers an area of 300 million hectares and is home to the world's second largest tropical forest. It is also a major supplier of illegal timber, part of a global trade that costs governments US $10 billion per year. 

Get the full story from Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO): http://ow.ly/qb97i

文章內容: Since January 2013, six previously polio-free countries have reported new outbreaks. Take a look at this video and story featuring UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador Mia Farrow, who says that it’s past time for polio to be finished and talks about contracting the disease as a child: http://j.mp/HxeL7Z

As the harvest begins in Burkina Faso, beneficiaries of World Food Programme's Cash for Assets activities are reaping the benefits of work done earlier in the year to improve rice production. "We and our children are no longer hungry", says one woman farmer. Get the full story at http://bit.ly/1aBXsfg

Greenhouse gases now in atmosphere will impact on planet for hundreds and thousands of years.

Find out more in the latest World Meteorological Organization publication released on Wednesday: http://goo.gl/xj7UWn

How can sport bring about peace?

From 6 to 8 November, more than 700 influential decision-makers and opinion-leaders from world sport governance, politics, NGOs and the private sector, plus academics and top-level athletes from over 100 countries will gather at the 7th Peace and Sport International Forum in Monaco.

For 3 days, these global figures will share ideas on how sport can contribute to peace processes around the globe.

Find out more at: http://j.mp/1h6oMtj

6 November marks the International Day for Preventing the Exploitation of the Environment in War and Armed Conflict.

Damage to the environment is often overlooked in discussions of war and conflict. As a consequence of a war, water wells have been polluted, crops torched, forests cut down, soils poisoned, and animals killed to gain military advantage.

Ensuring environmental protection is part of conflict prevention, peacekeeping and peacebuilding strategies.

Find more about the Day at: http://j.mp/bujMw3

文章內容:
Did you know that 38% of the world’s land is used for agriculture? Or that there are 4.4 million fishing vessels and 1.4 billion cattle in the world? 

See these and more facts and figures in this new Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) infographic: http://bit.ly/1g8QjJl

In Afghanistan, where poverty and insecurity are all too well known, social moblizers are quietly leading the fight to eradicate polio. Get the full story from UNICEF: http://uni.cf/1dkC9U4

Read 10 facts on polio from World Health Organization (WHO): http://j.mp/19F3GMf

With the world’s population expected to reach 9 billion by 2050, demands on agriculture will continue to grow. Share your views on how business can help meet the global challenges of food security and sustainable agriculture and help United Nations Global Compact develop new Sustainable Agriculture Business Principles. The online consultation ends 15 November. 

More details at http://j.mp/19QcPl4

Congratulations to international football star Yaya Tour?, who has was made an UNEP Goodwill Ambassador this week. The C?te d'Ivoire and Manchester City player has pledged to combat wildlife crime, in particular the illegal ivory trade that sees thousands of African elephants slaughtered each year. Read the full story at http://j.mp/19PmKr8

Join the Zero Hunger Challenge: http://j.mp/18eARYc

文章內容:
The United Nations Joint Programme on HIV/AIDS (UNAIDS) has released a supplement to the 2013 UNAIDS Report on the global AIDS epidemic focused on the issue HIV and aging.

The supplement reveals that out of the global total of 35.3 million people living with HIV, an estimated 3.6 million are people aged 50 years or older. The majority of them, 2.9 million people, are in low-and middle-income countries where the percentage of adults living with HIV who are 50 years or older is now above 10%. The supplement also reveals that in high-income countries almost one-third of people living with HIV are 50 years or older.

Find out more: http://j.mp/1dZD1xR

The Hunger Games movie, World Food Programme and Feeding America want you to join in their quest to #IgniteTheFight against hunger. No matter where you live, hunger isn’t as far away as you might think – often, it is right around the corner.

But by teaming up, you can build a better future for hungry children and families all over the world. Check it out: http://www.hungergames.com/

文章內容:
Fully biodegradable plates implanted with organic seeds in Colombia to provide food after use, a social media website to promote car-sharing in Viet Nam and certified cocoa for speciality markets are just some of the 34 winners of the 2013 SEED Awards, UNEP -- the UN Environment Programme -- announced this week. 

The awards support innovative social and environmental start-up enterprises, which can tackle key sustainable development challenges at the community level. Find out more at: http://j.mp/18JAj7E

Take a look at this video to see Lang Lang perform when he visited UN Headquarters in New York, and find out what he had to say about his new role: http://j.mp/1gWdkjS

Are you celebrating Halloween? Check out this Instavideo of Trick-or-Treat for UNICEF USA boxes from over the years: http://j.mp/1f5SXMJ

Find out how you can support UNICEF's work for children on Halloween and all year round at http://j.mp/1f5U6Ut

Each year, 7.3 million girls under 18 give birth in developing countries. Of these, 2 million are under age 15. Becoming a mother too young not only derails the development of young girls and prevents them from reaching their full potential but complications during pregnancy and childbirth can pose a risk to their lives. 

Find out more from UNFPA in the State of World Population 2013 report, out today:  www.unfpa.org/swop

A major new UNICEF campaign hopes to vaccinate 2.4 million children in Syria against measles/mumps/rubella, polio and other preventable diseases. Read more and find out how you can help Syrian children at http://j.mp/19Qek2z

UN expert on transitional justice Pablo de Greiff has called for clear goals on access to justice in the post-2015 development framework. 

“A limited and narrow approach to development, which ignores justice considerations, will not be human nor is it sustainable,” he told the UN General Assembly on Monday. 

Find out more from United Nations Human Rights: http://sm.ohchr.org/1aON1n5

The UN Academic Impact and Council on Foreign Relations are launching a new series of “talks” on global issues, starting on 1 November on “Biology’s Brave New World: Looking Toward Threats to Global Health”. 

Find out how you can participate either virtually or in person at http://bit.ly/1djPjkm

In the fight against climate change, the biggest emitters can make the biggest difference. See which countries are taking climate action in this new World Bank infographic showing the carbon markets of the world: http://wrld.bg/q3HtL  

Find out more about the UN’s work against climate change at http://j.mp/1ePSv52

Malaria and poverty are inextricably linked – take a look at this video from Roll Back Malaria to learn how: http://j.mp/1gN5Csa

Get key facts on malaria and find out about the work of the UN and its partners for a malaria-free world: http://j.mp/1eQigCj

Get full details at http://j.mp/virtualGSSD

Tuberculosis (TB) treatment has saved the lives of more than 22 million people since 1995, and the number of deaths from the disease fell to 1.3 million last year. "Take decisive action while we still can. It’s good for the planet -- and good for business."

文章內容:
The Global Green Growth Forum is taking place in Copenhagen, Denmark. On Monday, the head of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO), Jos? Graziano da Silva, told the event that reducing food loss and waste is key to fighting hunger. 

“If we reduce food loss and waste to zero it would give us additional food to feed 2 billion people,” he said. 

Get the full story at http://j.mp/1fQHROC

Find out more about achieving Zero Hunger at zerohungerchallenge.org

The 8th Internet Governance Forum takes place this week in Bali, from 22 to 25 October. If you can’t make it in person, you can still participate by watching the webcast of the event; following real-time closed captioning or even by organizing an IGF hub in your city! Find out more: http://bit.ly/igflive.

“Backpacks that save lives? You bet!” In this blog post, UN Special Envoy Ray Chambers explains how packs carried by community health workers in developing countries are providing millions of children and families with basic health needs: http://dld.bz/cPgu7

Waste not, want not. Every year, we waste or lose 1.3 billion metric tons of food – one-third of the world’s annual food production. Yet food wastage is one issue that we all can do something about now. 

Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) and UNEP explain here: http://j.mp/198huOW

文章內容:
17 October is the International Day for the Eradication of Poverty. 

The MDGs have been the most effective global anti-poverty push in history. The world has halved extreme poverty rates, millions more children go to school and more people have access to clean water. Many challenges remain: 1 in 8 people still go hungry and millions continue to face discrimination and lack of access to education, employment and better lives. 

Marking the Day, Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon said that together, we build a sustainable world of prosperity & peace, justice & equity. Find out more: bit.ly/123TTck

Nearly 842 million people worldwide -- 1 in 8 -- are chronically undernourished. Wednesday is World Food Day, this year calling attention to and how healthy people depend on healthy and sustainable food systems. 

Find out more and take a look at the winner of this year’s Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) poster design contest: http://bit.ly/OiIcfZ 

See how you can take up the Zero Hunger Challenge at zerohungerchallenge.org 

Make a difference and Watch Hunger Stop with the World Food Programme: http://mko.rs/VL
留言:
['Food insecurity is  a great risk for health in Canada for First Nation households on-reserve (Chan et al. 2011, 2012, Fieldhouse and Thompson 2013, Lawn and Harvey 2004) as well as off-reserve (Willows et al. 2009, 2011; Taraskuk et al. 2013). Household food insecurity rates in First Nation communities greatly surpass the Canadian average of 9.2 % and rates for sub-population groups such as the lowest income adequacy quintile (55%), social assistance recipients (62%) and off-reserve Aboriginals (33%)  (Health Canada, 2006).  Studies in northern Manitoba and northern Ontario reveal very high rates with all of these studies indicating food insecurity rates are above 75% (Lawn and Harvey, 2004a; Lawn and Harvey, 2004b; Thompson et al, 20012). Recent research shows that 41% of First Nation households on-reserve in B.C. and 38% of First Nation households on-reserves in Manitoba are food insecure: food insecurity rates range from 16% in southern First Nations to 73% in the northern communities.  However, a national study of food security in First Nation communities is not available and was not part of the Health Canada study in 2004 and 2009 for all non-First Nation communities.
Provisioning of country foods has been negatively impacted by many factors. These factors include: disruption of cultural transmission by residential schools; restrictions prohibiting the sale of wild fish and meat which has not been inspected at southern based federal food processors, and, poverty limiting the ability to buy the necessary gear (e.g., nets, boats, rifles, snowmobiles etc.), as well as to buy market food. 
Poor quality food environments amplify individual risk factors for obesity, food insecurity, and may explain some racial and socio-economic inequalities  in health and nutritional outcomes. There are also linkages to missing and murdered women – as the need to feed the family when in poverty puts women at risk. Household food insecurity is reflected in unhealthy dietary patterns such as the low intake of fruits and vegetables and is recognized as an important public health concern in Canada. Food-related health problems include heart disease, diabetes, high blood pressure, distress, depression, low immunity levels, dental caries and anemia. Elevated food insecurity rates may explain why Manitoba has the highest rate of pediatric diabetes in North America, particularly in the four Ojibway-Cree First Nation communities. 
Treaties were meant to ensure access to sustainable livelihoods and food security from country foods but subsistence economies have been undermined and undervalued for their critical role in ensuring food security.  The decline of hunting for food has increased the reliance on store-bought food and adoption of characteristic southern dietary habits associated with obesity, dental caries, anemia, lowered resistance to infection, diabetes and food insecurity. Nobel laureate Amartya Sen (1983) in his groundbreaking ‘Poverty and Famines: An Essay of Entitlement and Deprivation’ theorizes: “a person is reduced to starvation if some change occurs either in his endowment (e.g., alienation of land, loss of labor power, ill health) or in his exchange entitlement (e.g., fall in wages, rise in food prices, loss of employment, drop in price of foods he produces)” (p. 45).
This food insecurity is unjust and requires immediate interventions to support country food programs and other interventions proven to support food security. Each public health authority should put in place a mandate to put in place a food security plan.  As well, a monitoring program for Food Security should be done annually or bi-annually for First Nation communities until the rates are on par with the Canadian public. Food security and its consequences cannot be ignored any longer.

Sincerely:

References
Beaumier M, Ford J. Food insecurity among Inuit women exacerbated by socioeconomic Stresses and Climate Change. Can J Public Health 2010;101(3):196-201.
Chan, Laurie, Olivier Receveur, Donald Sharp, Harold Schwartz, Amy Ing, and Constantine Tikhonov. 2011. First Nations food, nutrition and environment study: Results from British Columbia (2008/2009). Prince George: University of Northern British Columbia. Available at http://www.fnfnes.ca.
Chan, Laurie, Olivier Receveur, Donald Sharp, Harold Schwartz, Amy Ing, Karen Fediuk, Andrew Black and Constantine Tikhonov. 2012. First Nations food, nutrition and environment study: Results from Manitoba (2010). Prince George: University of Northern British Columbia. Available at http://www.fnfnes.ca.
Chan, Hing Man, Karen Fediuk, Sue Hamilton, Laura Rostas, Amy Caughey, Harriet Kuhnlein, Grace Egeland, and Eric Loring. 2006. “Food Security in Nunavut, Canada: Barriers and Recommendations.” International Journal Of Circumpolar Health 65 (5): 416–431. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/17319086. 
Che J, Chen J. Food insecurity in Canadian households: Health Reports. Statistics Canada’s analytical periodicals 2001;12(4):11-22. 
Fieldhouse, Paul, and Shirley Thompson. 2012. “Tackling Food Security Issues in Indigenous Communities in Canada: The Manitoba Experience.” Nutrition & Dietetics 69 (3) (September 16): 217–221. doi:10.1111/j.1747-0080.2012.01619.x. http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/j.1747-0080.2012.01619.x.
Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO). 1996. World Food Summit. Rome. 
Glacken, Jody. 2008. “First Nations and Inuit Health Branch, Health Canada. Promising Practices for Food Security. Draft Summary Report.”
Gorton, Delvina, Chris R Bullen, and Cliona Ni Mhurchu. 2010. “Environmental Influences on Food Security in High-income Countries.” Nutrition Reviews 68 (1) (January): 1–29. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20041997.
Hamelin, Anne-marie, Jean-pierre Habicht, and Micheline Beaudry. 1999. “Symposium: Advances in Measuring Food Insecurity and Hunger in the U . S . Food Insecurity: Consequences for the Household and Broader Social.” Journal of Nutrition 129 (2): 525–528.
Health Canada. Income-related household food security in Canada: Canadian Community Health Survey Cycle 2.2, Nutrition. Ottawa, ON: Health Canada, 2007.
Lawn J, Harvey D. Nutrition and Food Security in Kugaaruk, Nunavut: Baseline Survey for the Food Mail Pilot Project 2003. Ottawa, ON: Indian and Northern Affairs Canada, 2003.

7.	Thompson S., Wiebe, J., Gulrukh, A. & Ashram, A. (2012). Good news from UNICEF: Senegal now provides free access to health services for 2.5 million children under five. The new measure aims to accelerate reduction in child mortality, particularly for the poorest. Read more: uni.cf/GAM8Xn

Photo: UNICEF Senegal

A new report by World Bank finds 400 million children are still living in extreme poverty. Children accounted for one in three of those living in extreme poverty around the world in 2010, compared with only one in five of those living above the poverty line. In low-income countries, the percentages were even worse, with half of all children living in extreme poverty. 

Details and full report available at: http://j.mp/1fq83zl

The United Nations Human Rights approach for the Post 2015 development agenda is focused on a new agenda in which ALL human rights, including the right to development, are fully integrated. 

“This is what people across the world are demanding,” said UN Human Rights chief Navi Pillay. “Their cry is for a life lived with human dignity, a life free from fear and free from want, a life in which all human rights can be realized.”

More: http://sm.ohchr.org/15NVtkP

On Tuesday, Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon told the Budapest Water Summit that water holds the key to sustainable development but warned that, by 2030, nearly half the global population could be facing water scarcity and demand could outstrip supply by 40 per cent. 
Full story: http://j.mp/1e6HcVO

Find out more about achieving clean water for all: http://j.mp/wdsahO

留言:
['Dear Kavengo Matundu of United Nations Millennium Campaign in Naairobi Kenya, just come to join our last joint efforts to try reach the achievement of the Millennium Development Goals by 2015 for now there is an open cooperation with UNDP - Kinshsa DR Congo with our + SOCIAL GOOD SUMMIT - DR CONGO!!! Inform Madam Sylvie Mwichuli besides your team too!', 'Dear partners
Pippi house is a complete solution for girls who without financial help will have very small chances of gaining education, self-sufficiency, marriage and other things that we all want for our children. Right now we have 11 girls staying with us. They are between 15 and 24 years old. Our work method is similar to having foster children. Social workers build them psychologically and socially, Pippi house also receive English speaking volunteers from abroad on a regular basis. We provide longtime accommodation for three years with comfortable beds, good food, education, domestic skills and time for resting. There are today many different kinds of NGO-centers specialized in one specific area. Because of the tuff conditions the girls comes from, offering one service is often not enough for a sustainable positive development. Offering a complete solution helps the girls to focus on their schoolwork.

    Pippi girls at one picture      Living as a family at pippi house,                               First Day in Uniform to school.
   Our target group
Our target group has a high risk of diseases like HIV, alcoholism or getting a baby they can’t take good care of. The causes differ: poverty, abuse, lack of adult guidance. A lot of girls in Tanzania have good lives with caring parents, a home they attend school or a job. Our target group is the girls who do not. Homeless forced into labor or neglected by their parents. Girls who run away from home because of poverty, violence or similar problems often end up suffering from more violence then they eloped from. When teenage girls have run away there is often a long way back home. This is one of the goals of Pippi house: to help teenage girls reunite with their families. 
A common situation for teenage girls in Tanzania is to be working as housemaids. Anyone who is not in school and who is not supported by ones family needs to work for a living. However being an analphabetic will keep them and their future children in a cycle of poverty. We strongly encourage all employers of housemaids to offer to pay for their education. Here in Tanzania having had one employment is often not enough to gain a second job, these girls are very vulnerable when they are let go. 

 Volunteer Teaching,                           Girls on the way to school,                  Girls leaning how to make shanga,
The importance of girl’s education
 Rev.Aristides Nshange: After having worked with street boys for many years I found two things. Their mothers are often analphabetic and the fathers are often alcoholics. Educated girls are not in the same way at risk of their children running away from home. I find there to be a mentality with the idea that girls are not serious and that this would make it difficult to help them. From my experience I find this untrue. Girls who are given a fair chance to go to school are working very hard to succeed in their results. However; the consequences from malnutrition, psychological wounds and worrying can affect boys and girls in different ways. With supervision, guidance, instructions and motivation girls can do as well as their male classmates. 
There is a stigma around marrying uneducated women starting a negative spiral of shame where there should be encouragement and love for one another. Educated women are respected by the society and they are considered good wives and mothers. This makes them role models for young people showing them there is a way of fighting poverty. We most welcome committed women who have managed to do the journey from being less privileged in childhood to succeeding in adulthood. Come and visit us and inspire our girls!
Mothers spend a lot of time with their children; by being educated they are able to do so in a way that will strengthen the next generation of our country. Our girls will be able to teach their children English, math, the sky is the limit! Educated women often have fewer children then their fellow sisters, which increase their possibility to provide for their children’s basic needs and future education. 

      Girls back from school,	 Girls dancing at pippi house,                     Girls after Netball field,
Educated staff
The Pippi house staff consists of educated social workers with long experience from working with children at risk. The mother of the house has been working with Kishari boys home, Impact Kilimanjaro and Watoto foundation for many years. The fathers of the house have been working as a manager at Watoto foundation. As any social work we work with clients who have been threw a lot of challenges and unwanted experiences. It is crucial that our girls are being protected from further exposure to risk behaviors, but also people who can cause them harm by intention. We take this assignment very seriously. 

Volunteers’ visiting Girls                 , Volunteer Teaching Girls at pippi,         Founder& Director .pippi house,
We have volunteers coming here on a regular basis teaching the girls English, computer skills and math.

Future goals and needs
We want to expand our exclusive idea into other regions. Today our centre is located in Arusha, in the future we wish there to be similar centers in Iringa, Mbeya,Tanga, Bukoba, Manyara Morogoro and Singida. These are the cities we find most affected with girls child labour. Another of Pippi house future goals is to be a role model for others, similar organizations. 留言: ["Don't forget numerous traditional healers and Indigenous Health practitioners (THP) who using their ling term experiences passed on generation to treat malaria where allopathic doctors can’t reach OR BE CONVENIENT ACCESSIBLE. (Long cues in hospitals and health center or under stocked pharmacies can really deter patients to seek this kind of health care). A fact is that in a place where 1 healer is serving 200 - 800 persons compared to 1 doctor to 10.000- 20.000 persons (statistics of Uganda), the work on these practitioners is numerous in rolling back / controlling Malaria. In large programmes like Roll Back Malaria, I would like to see more the integration of the support and addressing challenges THP are facing in their work. When 50 – 80% of people in some nations relying on THP as health care opting, why development partner’s budget not focusing on THP who carrying the most burden in health service delivery?"]

留言:
["Working Together to Improve Lives and Expand Opportunities in Asia

For nearly sixty years, The Asia Foundation has been committed to improving lives across a dynamic and developing Asia. We partner with corporations and foundations to implement high-impact, results-driven programming that improves the lives of hundreds of thousands of people throughout Asia. Our private-sector partnerships, informed by The Asia Foundation's intimate understanding of local political, economic, and cultural environments throughout Asia, enable us to respond to the most urgent needs faced by the communities we serve flexibly and efficiently. Collaborations with private-sector partners are critical to our success in generating lasting impact, while simultaneously helping to achieve our partners' philanthropic, community engagement, and social responsibility goals.

We are proud to feature some of our partners below. Our shared successes with corporate and foundation partners are also featured prominently through high-visibility, award-winning multimedia campaigns, and at events throughout Asia and the United States."]

文章內容:
Released last weekend by the The Broadband Commission, the State of Broadband 2013 report is now available online for free download.

The Report finds that broadband is gradually becoming more affordable around the world, although it still remains out of reach for many. By mid-2013 some 134 countries were seen to have a national broadband strategy in place, but there remains a clear need for policy leadership to facilitate deployment in many areas.

Learn more about the State of Broadband 2013 report as well as other exciting outcomes at http://www.broadbandcommission.org.

["What is the #ReframingRio Education Project? 
It has been 20 years since the first Rio Earth Summit put sustainable development on the agenda, but what has happened since? More importantly, what still needs to be done?

Reframing Rio is a multimedia project which aims to reignite the global debate on the need to put sustainable pathways centre stage. The project aims to reach the maximum number of viewers by combining films with publications, social networking and educational resources.

The Reframing Rio Education Project aims to engage your students with the debate, to foster understanding the context of the Rio Earth Summit and Rio 20+ and encourage them to take action! The different 'Reframing Rio' films can be viewed separately and used to complement existing lessons or you can choose to work through the full set of lesson plans. 

https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=10151597542026537"]

Monday's International Youth Day focuses on youth migration. A third of international migrants are under 25 years old, like Akhtar, a young Afghan migrant who has travelled across continents for for years to find a place to call home. He has been rejected for asylum in every country on his journey. This video is his story.

More on #YouthDay here: http://bit.ly/cFFIzZ

文章內容:
Friday is the International Day of the World's Indigenous Peoples.

Message from United Nations Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon: "Indigenous peoples have made clear that they want development that takes into account culture and identity and the right to define their own priorities.  The post-2015 development agenda needs therefore to incorporate the rights, perspectives and needs of indigenous peoples."

Read more: http://bit.ly/1cKaZUw

Photo: Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon addresses participants at the 2012 International Day of the World’s Indigenous Peoples. To his left is Grand Chief Edward John, Chairperson of the UN Permanent Forum on Indigenous Issues.

Few young people receive adequate preparation for their sexual lives. This leaves them potentially vulnerable to coercion, abuse and exploitation, unintended pregnancy and sexually transmitted infections (STIs), including HIV.

UNFPA advocates for and supports the promotion of comprehensive age appropriate sexuality education. We also provide programming guidance for both, school and community settings, and advocate for wider educational opportunities for all young people with an emphasis on marginalized and adolescent girls!

['Promoting the rule of law at the national and international levels is at the heart of the United Nations’ mission. Establishing respect for the rule of law is fundamental to achieving a durable peace in the aftermath of conflict, to the effective protection of human rights, and to sustained economic progress and development. The principle that everyone – from the individual right up to the State itself – is accountable to laws that are publicly promulgated, equally enforced and independently adjudicated, is a fundamental concept which drives much of the United Nations work.
http://www.un.org/en/ruleoflaw/index.shtml
The principle of the rule of law embedded in the Charter of the United Nations encompasses elements relevant to the conduct of State to State relations. The main United Nations organs, including the General Assembly and the Security Council, have essential roles in this regard, which are derived from and require action in accordance with the provisions of the Charter.', "In keeping with Madiba's wish, on this special day moladi handed over a house constructed for a homeless Gogo (84) https://fbcdn-sphotos-e-a.akamaihd.net/hphotos-ak-ash4/1004816_10151769295915539_1459140309_n.jpg", 'Improving the lives of slum dwellers is

文章內容:
The vast majority – 90 per cent -- of the pregnant adolescents in the developing world are married. But for far too many of these girls, pregnancy has little to do with informed choice. Often it is a consequence of discrimination, rights violations (including child marriage), inadequate education or sexual coercion.

Adolescent pregnancy is a health issue: the youngest mothers face a heightened risk of maternal complications, death and disability, including obstetric fistula. Their children face higher risks as well.

Thursday is World Population Day: http://bit.ly/9djiqp

(image via UNFPA)

留言: ['The 2015 deadline for the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) is only 2 1/2 years away yet Kenya is very far from achieving the health targets set in 2000.  Currently, under-five mortality is estimated at 74/1,000 live births, while Infant  Mortality is 52/1,000. In Kenya,  little progress has been made in reducing the unde-five mortality rate of 99/1,000 recorded before the launch of the MDGs, with the under-five mortality rate going down by 15% since 1990. At  the  current rate, the  under-five mortality rate is almost 2.5 times the MDG target of 33/1,000 by 2015. Resource Hub for Development (RHD)-Kenya has  been supporting the developmental efforts channeled towards attaininig MDGs. @ http://www.kenyadev.org \r\n']

Soils are among the planet’s most vital natural resources, they're crucial for food security. But soils face many threats, such as climate change, overpopulation and erosion. 

Don’t miss this video to learn how the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) is working to preserve soils: http://bit.ly/18jU4Dd

“School feeding assures that where quality education is available, children are able to take advantage of the opportunity to learn,” said World Food Programme Executive Director Ertharin Cousin.

Find out about the first-ever report on the State of School Feeding Worldwide: http://j.mp/134MzyQ

In this photo taken in Mali, children get the calories and nutrition they need while giving them an added incentive to keep coming to class. Credit: WFP/Daouda Guirou

文章內容:
Global economic growth will continue to be “below potential” this year, according to a report released this week by the Development Policy and Analysis Division of UN-DESA that adds that job creation will be vital to spur recovery.

The UN World Economic Situation and Prospects (WESP) 2013 mid-year update notes that, since late 2012, new policy initiatives in major developed economies have reduced systemic risks and helped stabilize consumer, business and investor confidence, but with very limited improvement in economic growth.

Find out more here: http://j.mp/12ZTglI
Full report: http://bit.ly/WESP

文章內容:
Equality or bust for post-2015 global development goals.

This week a group United Nations Human Rights experts call for the post-2015 development agenda to be urgently refocused on equality, social protection and accountability. The statement came as UN Member States met to discuss how to shape a new set of global development goals. 

Read the statement: http://sm.ohchr.org/13HFiap

文章內容:
Although seemingly abundant, only a tiny amount of the water on our planet is easily available as freshwater. We live in an increasingly water insecure world where demand often outstrips supply and where water quality often fails to meet minimum 
standards. Under current trends, future demands for water will not be met. 

Wednesday is International Day for Biological Diversity which this year celebrates water and biodiversity. More: http://j.mp/kbGWWZ

文章內容:
Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon and World Bank Group President Jim Yong Kim are now on a historic joint visit to Africa's Great Lakes Region. 

This visit is important for two reasons - it highlights a new era of global institutions working together to promote stability, and it signals to the citizens of fragile and conflict affected nations our commitment: we will not leave you behind.

While there, they are meeting with African leaders to discuss solutions to helping the people of the Great Lakes prosper.

If you were part of this visit, what solutions would you offer?

Read more: http://bit.ly/12o0zTG

文章內容:
The World Federation of United Nations Associations recently published the latest edition of its journal, ACRONYM, on "2015 and Beyond: Perspectives on Global Development."

This issue aims to invite the reader into an imaginary UN conference room, where leading global opinion makers from different sectors have gathered to share their views on the post-2015 process. Contributing authors include United Nations Development Programme - UNDP Administrator Helen Clark, the Liberian Head of State and Co-Chair of the High Level Panel on Post-2015 President Ellen Johnson Sirleaf and Unilever CEO and High Level Panel Member Paul Polman. 

Read ACRONYM at: http://www.wfuna.org/acronym.
As of this week more than half a million citizens have toldthe United Nations their priorities for a better world. There is still time to vote!  Details are here:  http://goo.gl/tAmvM

Civil registration generates data for 42 out of the 60 indicators that help measure progress on achieving the MDGs:  http://www.who.int/topics/millennium_development_goals/en/

留言:
['MANIFESTO

Care for Maranao Women against Maternal Mortality (CARE MAAMA PLEASE)
Quote from   jointly published by PMNCH, WHO and Aga Khan University 
12 December 2011. From face book
Poor maternal, newborn and child health remains a significant problem in developing countries. Worldwide, 358 000 women die during pregnancy and childbirth every year and an estimated 7.6 million children die under the age of five. The majority of maternal deaths occur during or immediately after childbirth. The common medical causes for maternal death include bleeding, high blood pressure, prolonged and obstructed labor, infections and unsafe abortions. A child’s risk of dying is highest during the first 28 days of life when about 40% of under-five deaths take place, translating into three million deaths. Up to one half of all newborn deaths occur within the first 24 hours of life and 75% occur in the first week. Globally, the main causes of neonatal death are preterm birth, severe infections and asphyxia. Children in low-income countries are nearly 18 times more likely to die before the age of five than children in high-income countries.

It is a sacred responsibility of every male member of a civilize society to be concerned in the Maternal period of our respected Women it must be a prime duty to ensure that this women will be care in the highest standard attention. Forget the dominant attitude of some male of being proud as breed winner, Macho effect and doesn’t care for women’s affair that thinking exist only in the time of Conan the barbarian. 	Mass Communication  to the objectives of the cause
	Mass involvement of our people and make understand the message
	Ensure that every pregnant woman will get proper medical services established data center to record individual pregnant woman history to be done by barangay (village)official, or designation of barangay(village) midwife the involvement of our barangay(village) officials are very essential to this project.
	Ensure presence of midwife in time of delivery or patience is in Hospital if necessary.

By our joint efforts  INSALLAH (if God willing ) we can achieved this goal in line with the United Nation Millennium GOALS of 2015  Improved Maternal Health and reduce Child Mortality.

文章內容:
Genetic resources are invaluable to food security and nutrition. However, biodiversity, and in particular genetic diversity, is being lost at an alarming rate.

For the past 30 years, the Commission on Genetic Resources for Food and Agriculture of Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) has promoted a world without hunger by protecting genetic diversity. Find out what is being discussed during its meeting this week in Rome: http://bit.ly/103NmU8

文章內容:
In case you missed it...

It was announced last week that the Food Price Index from the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) increased by 1 percent in March driven mainly by a rise in dairy prices as hot, dry weather in Oceania led to decreased milk production. Meanwhile, the 2012 crop production estimate has been revised upward by nearly 3 million tonnes. 

Read the latest from FAO on food prices: http://bit.ly/ZOzuWA

文章內容:
A new report launched on Monday by UNICEF says that stunting affects about 1 in 4 children, preventing them from developing to their full potential.

Stunting is caused by several factors including poor nutrition, lack of proper care, inadequate health care and an unhealthy environment in the 1,000-day period, covering pregnancy and the first two years of a child's life. 

More information is here: http://uni.cf/11f5tTx

	Ensure presence of midwife in time of delivery or patience is in Hospital if necessary.

By our joint efforts  INSALLAH (if God willing ) we can achieved this goal in line with the United Nation Millennium GOALS of 2015  Improved Maternal Health and reduce Child Mortality.
CLOSE
Please keep in touch and like this manifest.', 'Congratulations:.keep up the good work! Young generations counting good people like you']

To whom it may concern,

Please could you afford us the time to explain what TPTT Academy is all about.  I need to find out if your organisation would be able to assist in funding/bursaries for disadvantaged students in the travel & tourism industry?

In 2012 I opened my own Travel Agency, and I went to some of our colleges in the Gauteng/Tswane area to do some research on what the future holds for our tourism students.  Are they getting the correct exposure etc.  I have found and was shocked as to the students knowledge of geography and of tourism.  I had a student, she was studying tourism and was in her 3rd year and she did not even know where Sandton in Gauteng was.  Her parents have paid over R60 000.00 over the 3 years for her to study, which to me is a lot of money.  And I cannot really say that I was very impressed with some of these colleges.  Shocking to say the least.

Our students are our future, and we have to invest in them!!

Herewith a little more information on TPTT Academy.

We are a Travel Academy (Travel Practical Training Tours Academy).  We assist the travel & tourism students with practical educational tours.  We 
The mission of TPTT Academy is to provide students opportunities to build knowledge through experiences beyond the classroom.  Students learn best when skills and concepts are integrated into real-life situations and lots of hands-on learning opportunities are provided.  The retention of this knowledge is best achieved when students have personal memories tied to the learning experiences.
TPTT Academy offers a variety of educational training tours to help travel & tourism students learn about the travel industry in order to succeed as a travel professional working in an agency or pursue their own home-based travel business.
We have over 17 years combined experience in providing the utmost in quality, authenticity and service in the educational, sport and corporate group travel industry. 
We are passionate about travel – and we want you to be too.', "QUESTION TO THE UNITED NATIONS FOUNDATION IN USA:

Why the UN does not vote deaths laws against those UN's country members abusive of the UN Millennium Development Gaols by 2015...as the war crime laws? e.g. An authority or officer misappropriates the funds which could save 1000 children or women...affected by the malaria..., for that misappropriation process, 9500 children or pregnant women lost their lives, so I would like to know if that does not merit or deserve to be involved within war crime according to the UN's war crime process?"]

文章內容:
Too many children travel long distances on foot, or by bus, boat, bicycle, rickshaw, sled or subway to get to school. They brave deserts, mountains, rivers, snow and ice. These images carry a message of hope -- if there is a will there is a way, but children can't do it alone. We must help them on their journey -- families, communities, public authorities and private sector partners. Together, we can help them overcome the obstacles, get to school and stay. Education is a human right.

An exhibit supported by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) showcasing these stories is now on display at UN Headquarters in New York city but you can see it online in this video.
留言: ['Need to make this a priority everywhere. A PBS special to start.', 'well done UN Millennium Development Goals']

文章內容:
The Kingdom of Swaziland in the south of Africa with a population of a million people carries a terrible burden: the world’s highest rate of tuberculosis (TB) and very high levels of co-infection with HIV. TB is the leading killer of people living with HIV/AIDS, and 80% of TB cases in Swaziland are HIV-positive. Furthermore, it is estimated that almost half of all people with TB in the country are not detected or notified. 

Ahead of Sunday's World Tuberculosis Day, World Health Organization (WHO) is sharing 10 photos illustrating what WHO, the national TB programme and partners are doing to find and treat people with TB early. 

See them here: http://www.who.int/features/2013/swaziland_tb/en/index.html. A 

Photos: WHO/H.M. Dias

There were so many inspiring images of women posted this week for International Women's Day.  Here is one shared by our ifad colleagues showing how women in rural areas play a critical role in running households and make major contributions to agricultural production. But the inequalities that exist between women and men make it difficult for women to reach their full potential.
 
In this photo, women harvest rice in Aljamdou village, Gambia. 

See all the images here:
http://photos.ifad.org/asset-bank/action/viewHome
